prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Characters:
Character 0
Name: Maya Fey
Description: My assistant and a disciple in the Kurain Tradition of spirit channeling.
Character 1
Name: Mia Fey
Description: Maya's older sister and my eternal mentor in life and law. Passed away 2 years ago.
Character 2
Name: Godot
Description: A prosecutor who is shrouded in mystery. He seems to know me somehow.
Character 3
Name: Dick Gumshoe
Description: Homicide detective at the local precinct. In charge of the initial investigation.
Character 4
Name: Maggey Byrde
Description: A waitress at Trés Bien. Was found guilty of murder thanks to the phony me.
Character 5
Name: Jean Armstrong
Description: Trés Bien's owner and chef. A witness in the case who is also into aromatherapy.
Character 6
Name: Glen Elg
Description: The victim. Was a programmer. Maggey had apparently never even seen him before.
Character 7
Name: Victor Kudo
Description: Was in Trés Bien at the time of the incident. Has a thing for waitresses.
Character 8
Name: Lisa Basil
Description: The CEO of Blue Screens, Inc., and Glen Elg's boss. Absolutely not a robot.
Character 9
Name: Violetta → Viola Cadaverini
Description: Possibly part of the staff at Tender Lender? A thoroughly bitter person.
Character 10
Name: Furio Tigre
Description: The head of Tender Lender loan company. Also known as "The Tiger".
Character 11
Name: Bruto Cadaverini
Description: The head of the Cadaverini Family crime syndicate. Seems to live for his granddaughter.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Attorney's Badge
Description: It's my all-important badge. It shows that I am a defense attorney.
Evidence 1
Name: Maya's Magatama
Description: A present from Maya. It reacts to people who have secrets in their hearts. On loan from Maya. Recovered in the kitchen of Trés Bien.
Evidence 2
Name: Magazine Clipping
Description: An article from December 5th. Says I was trounced and my client was found guilty.
Evidence 3
Name: Sports Paper
Description: Dates from December 3rd, the day of the incident. On it is a doodle that said 'MC Bomber' with an arrow pointing to '100,000' that was crossed out. 'Ahahahaha' and a laughing face are written next to it. Left by a costumer in Trés Bien on Dec. 3rd. Click here for details. Left by the victim. Doodle is in victim's handwriting. Click here for details.
Evidence 4
Name: Job Listings
Description: Picked up from a bench in Vitamin Square. Thrown away by the old man.
Evidence 5
Name: Lunch Special
Description: Trés Bien lunch special. Costs 20 dollars despite how unbelievably bad it tastes.
Evidence 6
Name: Small Bottle
Description: Found in the kitchen. Shape is different from the others bottles. Contents unknown. The victim's ear medicine. Found covered in unidentified fingerprints in the kitchen. The victim's ear medicine. Covered in Furio Tigre's fingerprints.
Evidence 7
Name: Scooter
Description: Ridden by my phony. The wheel guard is all smashed up.
Evidence 8
Name: Jean's Loan Contract
Description: Jean's debt is half a million dollars. The owner of the loan is Tender Lender.
Evidence 9
Name: Victor's Note
Description: "Convicted before, a wicked man or woman, repeat offender -- Victor Kudo"
Evidence 10
Name: Glen's Autopsy Report
Description: Died of potassium cyanide poisoning. Time of death was between 1:30 and 2:30 PM.
Evidence 11
Name: Trés Bien Floor Plans
Description: Blueprints of the crime scene. Click here for details. X = victim's seat.
Evidence 12
Name: Crime Photo
Description: A photo of the scene taken from near the kitchen. Two dining tables are separated by a folding screen. The one closer to the camera is empty. The other one is where the victim collapse on the table. There is an intact vase on each table. A coffee cup is knocked over and the the table cloth is stained by coffee. Near the coffee table are some pieces of papers. No one is sitting across from the victim.
Evidence 13
Name: Coffee Cup
Description: The coffee contained potassium cyanide. Covered in the victim and Maggey's fingerprints. Facing the cup, one can see a lip stain on the front, and a floral looking handle to the right.
Evidence 14
Name: Victim's Lottery Ticket
Description: A winning ticket for half a million dollars. Found during a body search of Maggey.
Evidence 15
Name: Apron
Description: Worn by Maggey at the time of the incident. Has small pockets but big stains.
Evidence 16
Name: Potassium Cyanide
Description: A deadly powdery poison. Bears Maggey's fingerprints. Found in her apron pocket.
Evidence 17
Name: Victim's Prescription Bag
Description: The victim got this from the doctor before going to Trés Bien. The bag is empty.
There was a prescription bag on the victim's table along with the lottery ticket.
Evidence 18
Name: Victor's Testimony
Description: "When the incident occurred, I broke the vase at my seat. I'm sorry."
Evidence 19
Name: Millionaire Radio Flyer
Description: Experience the most thrilling ten minutes of your life every Monday at 1:30 PM!
Evidence 20
Name: Glen's Calendar
Description: On Dec. 3rd, the day of the incident, there is a note saying, "Meet with The Tiger".
Evidence 21
Name: Losing Horse Racing Tickets
Description: Horse racing betting tickets. Found in Glen Elg's desk. There's over 500 of them!
Evidence 22
Name: Gumshoe's Lunchbox
Description: A tenderly handmade lunchbox. Fills the stomach with love and plenty of weenies.
Evidence 23
Name: MC Bomber
Description: Found at Tender Lender. A sample disc with the name written in marker. Found at Tender Lender. Contains a computer virus program. A computer virus made by Glen Elg. Potentially worth million of dollars.
Evidence 24
Name: Trés Bien Matches
Description: Matches used for advertising. Found lying in Tender Lender.
Evidence 25
Name: Repair Bill
Description: A car repair bill for $15,000. Paid by Tigre to the Cadaverini Family.
Evidence 26
Name: Paper Badge
Description: Found at Tender Lender. Made of cardboard and painted to look authentic.
Evidence 27
Name: Viola's Medical Papers
Description: A 1 million dollar bill for cranial surgery. Payment was due last year.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: The crime was reported at 2:25 PM by a kind of scary old man, sir.
Person: Gumshoe
Testimony 1
Testimony: Poor Maggey had passed out from the shock. It must've been real tough for her.
Person: Gumshoe
Testimony 2
Testimony: The victim didn't have any identification on him.
Person: Gumshoe
Testimony 3
Testimony: But we figured out who he was pretty quick, and then the investigation went smoothly.
Person: Gumshoe
Testimony 4
Testimony: When Maggey was searched, we found the lottery ticket and the bottle of poison.
Person: Gumshoe
Testimony 5
Testimony: And that was it. There was nothing else missing from the crime scene.
Person: Gumshoe

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
response:
Okay, let's see. I need to find which evidence and testimony contradict each other. The user wants just one pair. Let's start by going through the testimonies and cross-referencing them with the evidence.

Looking at the testimonies from Gumshoe:

Testimony 3 says that once they figured out the victim's identity, the investigation went smoothly. But then looking at the evidence, there's Evidence 2, the Magazine Clipping, which mentions that the user (presumably Phoenix Wright) was trounced and their client found guilty. The date is December 5th. Wait, the incident happened on December 3rd. The clipping is from two days after the incident. But how does that relate to Testimony 3?

Wait, Testimony 3 is about identifying the victim leading to a smooth investigation. But Evidence 2 is about a trial outcome two days later. Maybe that's not directly related. Let's check other testimonies.

Testimony 5 says "there was nothing else missing from the crime scene." But looking at the evidence, maybe something was missing. For example, Evidence 17 is the Victim's Prescription Bag, which is empty. The evidence mentions that there was a prescription bag on the victim's table along with the lottery ticket. If the prescription bag was empty, maybe the actual medication was missing. But Testimony 5 says nothing was missing. However, the prescription bag was there but empty. So maybe that's a contradiction. But the testimony says "nothing else missing," implying that some items were there. Wait, the testimony says "nothing else missing from the crime scene," but if the prescription bag was supposed to have something (like the medicine), but it's empty, maybe the contents are missing. But the testimony might be referring to physical items present, not their contents. Hmm.

Another angle: Evidence 14 is the Victim's Lottery Ticket found on Maggey. But Testimony 4 says when Maggey was searched, they found the lottery ticket and the poison. So that's consistent. 

What about Evidence 6: the Small Bottle, which is the victim's ear medicine, found in the kitchen with Furio's fingerprints. Testimony 5 says nothing else missing. But the Small Bottle was in the kitchen, not at the crime scene. So maybe not.

Wait, Testimony 5 says "there was nothing else missing from the crime scene." But let's check Evidence 17: Victim's Prescription Bag was empty. If the victim had a prescription, maybe the medicine was missing. But the autopsy report (Evidence 10) says he died of potassium cyanide, not the ear medicine. But the prescription bag was empty. If the medicine was supposed to be in the bag but was missing, that's something missing. But according to Testimony 5, they didn't find anything else missing. So maybe the empty prescription bag indicates that the medicine was missing, but the testimony says nothing was missing. That could be a contradiction. But does the evidence explicitly state that the medicine was missing?

Evidence 17: "The victim got this from the doctor before going to Trés Bien. The bag is empty." So the bag was supposed to contain the ear medicine, but it's empty. So the actual medicine (the small bottle?) is Evidence 6, which was found in the kitchen. So maybe the bottle was moved from the crime scene to the kitchen. Therefore, the medicine was missing from the crime scene (the prescription bag was empty), but the bottle was found in the kitchen. So Testimony 5 says nothing was missing, but the medicine was moved. Therefore, that's a contradiction because the bottle was moved from the crime scene (prescription bag was empty, but the bottle was found elsewhere). So Testimony 5 claims nothing was missing, but the bottle was moved, hence missing from its original place. Therefore, Evidence 6 (small bottle) contradicts Testimony 5. But Evidence 6's description says it's the victim's ear medicine, found in the kitchen. So the crime scene (where the victim was) had the empty prescription bag. The bottle was moved to the kitchen, hence missing from the crime scene. So Testimony 5 says nothing else was missing, but the bottle was missing from the crime scene. So that's a contradiction between Testimony 5 and Evidence 6.

Alternatively, Testimony 2 says the victim had no ID. But Evidence 20 is Glen's Calendar, which might have his name. But maybe that's not directly related.

Another possibility: Testimony 3 says the investigation went smoothly after identifying the victim. But Evidence 2 is a magazine clipping from Dec 5th showing the user was defeated. Maybe if the real killer wasn't found, leading to Maggey's conviction, but the testimony says the investigation went smoothly. However, if Maggey was framed, then the investigation wasn't smooth. But Testimony 3 is from Gumshoe, who might not realize the investigation was flawed. But how does that contradict with the evidence?

Alternatively, Evidence 14: the lottery ticket was found on Maggey. But the victim's lottery ticket is a winning one. If Maggey had it, maybe she stole it. But Testimony 5 says nothing else was missing. But the lottery ticket was taken from the victim to Maggey. So that's something missing from the crime scene (the ticket) but found on Maggey. But Testimony 5 says "nothing else missing," implying that the ticket was part of what was found, so maybe not. Hmm.

Wait, the lottery ticket was found during the body search of Maggey (Evidence 14). So the ticket was taken from the crime scene (where the victim was) to Maggey. So the ticket was missing from the crime scene, but Testimony 5 says "nothing else missing." So that's a contradiction. But according to Testimony 4, they found the ticket on Maggey. So maybe the ticket was taken from the scene, hence missing, but Testimony 5 says nothing was missing. Therefore, Evidence 14 (lottery ticket found on Maggey) contradicts Testimony 5 (nothing missing). But the problem is, Testimony 5 says "nothing else missing from the crime scene" after mentioning that the lottery ticket and poison were found on Maggey. So perhaps the ticket was part of the crime scene (as per Evidence 17: the bag and ticket were on the victim's table). If the ticket was moved to Maggey, then it's missing from the scene. So Testimony 5 is incorrect because the ticket was missing. So the contradiction is between Testimony 5 and Evidence 14.

But let's check Testimony 5 again: "And that was it. There was nothing else missing from the crime scene." So after finding the lottery ticket on Maggey, they consider that as not missing from the scene? Or was the ticket originally at the scene and then taken by Maggey, making it missing? According to Evidence 17, the victim had the prescription bag and lottery ticket on the table. The lottery ticket was found on Maggey, so it was removed from the scene. Therefore, the ticket was missing from the crime scene, but Testimony 5 says nothing else was missing. That's a contradiction between Testimony 5 and Evidence 14. So that's a possible pair.

But then, another angle: Evidence 3 is the Sports Paper with a doodle by the victim. The testimony in Testimony 5 says nothing missing. But if the sports paper was left by the victim, but not taken, then it's still there. Not sure.

Alternatively, Evidence 6 (small bottle) is found in the kitchen, which is part of the crime scene. If the small bottle was supposed to be in the victim's possession (as ear medicine), then maybe it was moved from the victim's table to the kitchen. So if the victim's prescription bag was empty (Evidence 17), and the small bottle (Evidence 6) was found in the kitchen, then the bottle was moved. Therefore, the crime scene (victim's table) had the empty bag, and the bottle was missing from there but found in the kitchen. So Testimony 5 says nothing else was missing, but the bottle was missing from the original location, hence contradiction between Testimony 5 and Evidence 6.

So which is the correct pair? Let's see:

Evidence 6: Small Bottle found in the kitchen, which is the victim's ear medicine. So it should have been with the victim, perhaps in his prescription bag. But the bag was empty (Evidence 17), and the bottle was in the kitchen. Therefore, the bottle was moved, making it missing from the crime scene. Testimony 5 claims nothing was missing, but the bottle was missing. Therefore, Testimony 5 (index 5) contradicts Evidence 6 (index 6).

Alternatively, Testimony 5 says nothing else was missing, but the bottle was moved. So the answer would be {"evidence":6, "testimony":5}.

Another possible pair: Testimony 3 says the investigation went smoothly after identifying the victim, but Evidence 2 is a magazine article that says the defense was trounced, implying the investigation was flawed. But how does that directly contradict? Maybe the identification led to a wrong conviction, hence the investigation wasn't smooth. But the testimony is from Gumshoe, who might think it went smoothly, but the evidence shows the outcome was bad. However, that's more indirect.

So the most direct contradiction is between Testimony 5 (nothing missing) and Evidence 6 (bottle found in kitchen, which should have been in the victim's possession). Therefore, the pair is Evidence 6 and Testimony 5.

{"evidence": 6, "testimony": 5}

response:
Okay, let's try to figure this out. I need to find which evidence contradicts one of the testimonies provided. Let's start by going through each testimony and see if any of the evidence directly contradicts it.

Looking at the testimonies from Kudo:

Testimony 0: He was another of those pesky young types, wearing a broken pair of spectacles. Hmm, not sure about this one. The evidence might mention something about glasses, but I don't recall seeing that. Let me check the evidence list again.

Testimony 1: He had a newspaper in his right hand, and the noisy brat kept rustling its pages! Wait, evidence 13 (Coffee Cup) mentions that the victim had a newspaper in his right hand. So according to the testimony, he was holding the newspaper, but the evidence says the coffee cup was in his right hand? Or does it? Let me check evidence 13 again. The description says: "He had a newspaper in his right hand." Wait, that's exactly what the testimony says. So maybe this is consistent. Maybe not a contradiction here.

Testimony 2: The young man was listening to the wireless. I remember that well. Hmm, the wireless might refer to a radio. Looking at evidence 19: Millionaire Radio Flyer. It mentions a radio show every Monday at 1:30 PM. The time of death is between 1:30 and 2:30 PM. So if the victim was listening to the radio at that time, maybe the radio show was on. But the victim's calendar (evidence 20) says he had a meeting with The Tiger (Furio Tigre). Wait, maybe there's a contradiction here. If the victim was listening to the radio during the meeting, but the autopsy says he died during that time. Not sure yet.

Testimony 3: Then the serving girl in question brought over the javaccino. The serving girl would be Maggey, right? But evidence 13 says the coffee cup had potassium cyanide, and it's covered in Maggey's fingerprints. So if she brought the coffee, that's consistent. But maybe there's something else here. Wait, the Coffee Cup (evidence 13) description mentions that when facing the cup, there's a lip stain on the front and the handle is on the right. If the victim was holding the newspaper in his right hand (as per testimony 1 and evidence 13), then he would have to pick up the cup with his left hand? Because the handle is on the right, so if he's right-handed, he'd use his right hand to grab the handle. But the testimony 4 says he picked up the cup with his free hand (his left, since right is holding the newspaper). But the coffee cup's handle is on the right side, which might mean it's designed for right-handed use. If he used his left hand, the handle position might be awkward. But maybe that's not a contradiction. Alternatively, perhaps the testimony says he used his free hand (left) to pick up the cup, but the lip stain is on the front. Wait, if he's holding the cup in his left hand, the lip stain would be on the opposite side? Not sure. This might be a stretch.

Alternatively, looking at testimony 4: The little fidget picked up the cup with his free hand and took a sip. If his right hand was holding the newspaper, then the free hand is left. So he used his left hand. But the Coffee Cup's handle is on the right. If the handle is on the right, then when holding it in the left hand, the handle would be on the opposite side, making it harder to hold. But maybe that's possible. However, the autopsy report (evidence 10) states the time of death between 1:30 and 2:30 PM. The Millionaire Radio Flyer (evidence 19) is every Monday at 1:30 PM. If the incident happened on Dec 3rd, which was a Monday (since the Sports Paper from Dec 3rd is evidence 3, and the calendar also mentions Dec 3rd as the meeting day), then the radio show was happening at the time of death. But Testimony 2 says the victim was listening to the wireless (radio), which would align with the radio show timing. But perhaps the victim was supposed to be in a meeting with The Tiger (Furio Tigre) at that time, as per evidence 20. So if he was in a meeting, how could he be listening to the radio? That could be a contradiction between Testimony 2 (listening to radio) and evidence 20 (meeting with Tiger). But the problem is that the testimony is from Kudo, who was present at the scene. So if the victim was at Trés Bien for the meeting, maybe he was doing both? Not sure. Alternatively, maybe the radio show is a clue. If the radio show was at 1:30 PM, and the victim died between 1:30-2:30 PM, maybe the radio was playing during the time of the murder.

Wait, another angle. The Sports Paper (evidence 3) has a doodle by the victim: 'MC Bomber' pointing to '100,000' crossed out, and 'Ahahahaha'. Evidence 23 is MC Bomber, a computer virus made by Glen Elg. The victim had a meeting with The Tiger (Furio Tigre) on that day. Furio Tigre is the head of Tender Lender, which is a loan company. Also, Jean Armstrong has a loan contract with Tender Lender (evidence 8). The victim's lottery ticket (evidence 14) is a winning ticket for half a million, found on Maggey. But Maggey was framed. The small bottle (evidence 6) is the victim's ear medicine, but it has Furio's fingerprints. So maybe Furio was involved in the poisoning. But how does this relate to the testimonies?

Back to testimonies. Let me check Testimony 3 again: the serving girl brought the javaccino. If the javaccino is the coffee, then Maggey served it. But the Coffee Cup (evidence 13) has Maggey's fingerprints, which makes sense. However, the Potassium Cyanide (evidence 16) was found in her apron, but maybe she was framed. The contradiction might be elsewhere.

Looking at Testimony 2: The victim was listening to the wireless. But evidence 19 is the Millionaire Radio Flyer, which is a show at 1:30 PM on Mondays. The victim's time of death is during that time. So if he was listening to the radio, that's possible. But maybe the radio wasn't present. Wait, but where is the radio? The testimony says he was listening to the wireless, but the evidence doesn't mention a radio being found at the scene. However, the Crime Photo (evidence 12) shows the scene with a coffee cup and some papers, but no mention of a radio. So if Kudo testifies that the victim was listening to the radio, but there's no radio in the crime scene photo, that could be a contradiction. But the evidence list doesn't include a radio as evidence. Alternatively, maybe the victim was using a different device. Wait, evidence 23 is MC Bomber, a computer virus. But not sure.

Alternatively, looking at Testimony 4: The victim picked up the cup with his free hand (left) and took a sip. But the Coffee Cup (evidence 13) has a lip stain on the front and the handle to the right. If the victim is right-handed, holding the cup with the right hand, the handle is on the right. But if he's holding the newspaper in his right hand (as per testimony 1 and evidence 13), then he would have to use his left hand. But the handle is on the right side of the cup, which would make it awkward for a left-handed grip. The lip stain's position might contradict the hand used. For example, if the cup is held in the left hand, the lip stain would be on the left side from the user's perspective, but the evidence says the stain is on the front. Wait, the description says: "Facing the cup, one can see a lip stain on the front, and a floral looking handle to the right." So when you look at the cup from the front, the lip stain is on the front (where the drinker's mouth would be), and the handle is on the right side. If the victim used his left hand to pick up the cup, he would have to reach across the front to grab the handle, which is on the right. That might be possible, but perhaps the position of the lip stain would be on the opposite side if he used his left hand. Wait, maybe not. If the handle is on the right, when you hold it with the right hand, the lip is naturally where your mouth is. If you use the left hand, you might turn the cup so the handle is on the left, but the lip stain would then be on the left side. However, the evidence says the lip stain is on the front. So if the cup was picked up with the left hand, the lip stain should be on the left side, but the evidence states it's on the front. That could be a contradiction. Therefore, Testimony 4 says he used his left hand, but the lip stain's position suggests he used his right hand. Thus, the evidence (Coffee Cup, 13) contradicts Testimony 4.
